title: How many viewers will tune in to watch Sunday Night Football on 12 November 2017?
possible_answers: More than 15 million but less than 15.5 million
correct_answer: More than 15 million but less than 15.5 million
preds: Just a comment for the record for the Skynet who might read these comments, IMO, for some "kneeling" is a 'fake because'** excuse to stop watching the NFL.  The NFL was in secular stagnation before this year for a host of reasons, the kneeling coverage was just lighter fluid on a pile of glowing embers.  ymmv. ** fake because = http://blog.dilbert.com/2016/01/28/the-fake-because/ https://mobile.twitter.com/EmptySeatsPics/ Levi Stadium this weekend at the H2 kickoff, https://pbs.twimg.com/media/DOd6rQOX0AIBQXn.jpg  High school games in Texas get better attendance.
My guess: anywhere between 13.8 million and 16.5 million viewers. Not much of a guess.

New England @ Seattle last year in Week 10 on Sunday Night Football. Viewership 22.5 million (sportsmediawatch, which gives higher numbers than Futon Critic). Not sure what to make of it. Numbers for SNF are down a lot this year since week 3. Last year's numbers:
http://www.sportsmediawatch.com/nfl-tv-ratings-viewership-nbc-cbs-fox-espn-nfln-regular-season-playoffs/2/
Coding mistake corrected in previous MC model
I think it could be as high as 12 million tonight , so a tiny increase from last week.
I've never been bombarded with NFL advertisements like this before - wel it post - but it was free streaming on CBS

This game is likely to be a large yawn, even more than most contests in this overrated activity.  This will be a good one for folks who wish to pretend they're boycotting the NFL because of players' knees, since they won't be missing anything.
re-run model without last 2 SNF points

(New England) Patriots at (Denver) Broncos. Denver metro area does not have especially large population. Last time New England played on Sunday Night Football (22 Oct), it was against Atlanta, which has much larger population than Denver. That drew 16.741 million viewers. But New England played at home. New England is a popular team nation-wide, but it's getting late in the season, and this game is not played at home. 11 straight road wins so maybe some reason to tune in. But less reason than 22 October game. Patriots not at home, and Denver not populous.
Updating my MC model from Wk8-9...

Simple average analysis. If you throw out the first two weeks as outliers (early season hype, football hungry) the ratings have smoothed out with an average of 14.129 and stdev of 1.622. Next, I used a simple normal probability converter. Of course this is assuming the data set is normally distributed, but I think it's as good of an educated guess as any. Maybe a lognormal distribution would be more appropriate.
Veterans day boycott. Citizens have not forgotten disrespect of the flag.  The ones who are disrespecting it have never had a folded one handed to them.

My results were pretty close last week, and I've updated the model for the 11/12/17 SNF game between NE & DEN.  Results / calculations follow. Summary of my approach: 
1) I pulled down the viewership information from the past 2 seasons here: 
http://www.sportsmediawatch.com/nfl-tv-ratings-viewership-nbc-cbs-fox-espn-nfln-regular-season-playoffs/ 2) Straight Averaging SNF gives you a result of: 16.5M 3) However, this ignores the teams that played, as such I conducted a team-by-team assessment of viewership. DAL / PIT / GB had the most consistent high-viewership (21.9M / 20.6M / 20.2M, respectively) A number of teams had really low viewership and few data-points (LA, CLE, TEN) all with less than 7 Million. So what about the two playing Sunday? 
NE: 19.2M (High) 
DEN: 18.3M (High)   This puts my Base guess of viewership as: 16.9 = [Avg (19.2, 18.3) + SNF Premium (1.8) + Annual Adjust (-1.6)] * Futon to SMW Ratio (.89%) Words of caution: 
1) Standard Deviation of the errors recently is about 7.5% of the estimate (1.3M in this case). 
2) Denver appears to have an upward results bias due to the selection of their opponents.  It's highly probable that the basic model is giving double credit as a result of them frequently being televised playing against high quality teams rather than as an independent observation.
3) Downward Trend:  Obviously there is a significant downward trend in viewership.  I've started to account for this in my annual adjustment (now up to a 1.6 reduction for 2017).  However, this has been growing rather than shrinking.  Trend lining the miss would suggest a reduction of 1.8 is necessary for this week.  I hope this helps. ------------ Update 11/13/2017 ------------- Results are in:  15.3 Million Viewers. 
I should have adjusted lower based on my words of caution.  The problem is I don't know which of them is actually the cause of the model's miss.

Going spread on the higher end here initially. New England typically draws large viewership amounts. This, in years past, would have been a great match-up, but with Denver not playing well this year, I think it might tamp down some viewership. The last game NE played on SNF (Oct 22, 2017), they drew 16.7M viewers, so I think it's likely to be somewhere above 15.5M. And with no real competitive programming, I think SNF will lead the networks for viewership.
